sections.title: Options Fundamentals
sections.content: Options are contracts that give the right, but not the obligation, to buy (call) or sell (put) an underlying asset at a specific price by a certain date. Calls profit when the underlying asset rises, while puts profit when it falls. Options can be used for speculation, income generation through covered calls, or protection through protective puts.

points.title: Strike Price
points.description: The price at which the option can be exercised - in-the-money options have intrinsic value.

points.title: Expiration Date
points.description: Options expire worthless if not exercised - time decay (theta) erodes value as expiration approaches.

points.title: Premium
points.description: The cost of the option - influenced by intrinsic value, time value, volatility, and interest rates.

sections.title: Options Are Wasting Assets
sections.content: Unlike stocks, options have expiration dates and lose value over time. This time decay accelerates as expiration nears, making timing crucial for option strategies.

sections.title: Common Strategies for Beginners
sections.content: Covered calls involve owning stock and selling call options for income. Protective puts act as insurance against stock declines. These strategies have defined risk but can enhance portfolio returns when used appropriately. Avoid naked options (selling options without the underlying asset) until you have significant experience.

sections.title: Beyond Options: Futures and Other Derivatives
sections.content: Futures contracts obligate delivery of an asset at a future date, commonly used for commodities, currencies, and indices. Other derivatives include swaps (exchange of cash flows) and forwards (customized agreements). These instruments are generally more suitable for institutional investors due to their complexity and leverage.

sections.title: Start Exploring Options Safely
steps: Open a brokerage account with options trading approval (requires additional application)
Paper trade options strategies for several months before risking real money
Start with covered calls on stocks you already own and plan to hold
Use options for protection during volatile market periods

sections.title: Options Aren't for Everyone
sections.content: Most individual investors achieve their financial goals through buy-and-hold investing. Use options sparingly for specific purposes like income generation or risk management, not as a primary strategy.
